We analyzed projects coming from <a href="https://bestof.js.org/" target="_blank">bestof.js.org</a>, a curated list of the best projects related to the web platform. Note that you can click on a project to get more info.</p></small><div><h3>Get the latest JS rankings in your inbox every week</h3><p>Sign up for <a href="https://bestof.js.org/" target="_blank">bestof.js.org</a>'s newsletter, and you'll receive exclusive stats about the most popular JavaScript projects each week.</p></div><section><div><h2>Most Popular Projects Vue, Angular</div></div><div>+9.7k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="gatsby"><div><div><img src="https://www.gatsbyjs.org/gatsby-negative.svg" width="50" height="50" alt="Gatsby" /></div><div><h4>Gatsby</h4><div>⚛️📄🚀 Blazing fast static site generator for React</div></div><div>+9.7k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><h3>Overview</h3><p>These are the hottest projects of the year, all categories included.</p><h3>Vue.js strikes again</h3><p>Once again, <a href="http://vuejs.org" target="_blank">Vue.js</a> is the trendiest project of the year, with more than 40,000 stars added on GitHub during the year.</p><p>It's far more than in 2016 (26,000 stars), and the gap with the next contender (<a href="https://reactjs.org" target="_blank">React</a>) is even bigger.</p><p>So what makes Vue.js special?</p><ul><li>First, it has a small learning curve, with a component approach similar to <a href="https://reactjs.org" target="_blank">React</a> but with a more familiar syntax.</li><li>The ecosystem is well defined, including a set of de-facto standards: router: <a href="http://router.vuejs.org/" target="_blank">vue-router</a>, State management library: <a href="https://vuex.vuejs.org" target="_blank">Vuex</a></li><li>The concept of single-file component that includes template, logic and styles in a single file <code>.vue</code> file is really nice.</li><li>It's used by one of the most popular PHP frameworks, <a href="https://laravel.com/" target="_blank">Laravel</a>, as its default view engine.</li><li>It's not backed by a big company of the Internet like Facebook or Google but maintained by <a href="https://github.com/yyx990803" target="_blank">Evan You</a> as an open-source project sponsored through crowd-sourcing.</li></ul><p>And this may be related with the last point, but Vue.js is very popular among developers from China. It's used by the biggest e-commerce platform of China (Alibaba), but also by companies like GitLab or Adobe.</p><h3>React, number 2, again!</h3><p>Like in 2016, <a href="https://reactjs.org" target="_blank">React</a> is number 2, with more than 27,000 stars added on GitHub (note that we're specifically talking about stars <em>added</em> over the year, not the <em>total</em> number of stars).</p><p><a href="https://github.com/facebookincubator/create-react-app" target="_blank">Create React App</a>, the third project, is the recommended way to start a new project with React, and its success made a lot of React boilerplates less relevant than before.</p><p><a href="https://github.com/gaearon" target="_blank">Dan Abramov</a> (the creator of <a href="http://redux.js.org" target="_blank">Redux</a>, now working for Facebook) did a great job, finding the right balance between simplicity and features. For example there is no fancy styling solution (just plain CSS), no server-side rendering, but everything is well packaged and the developer experience is really good.</p><h3>Axios</h3><p>The <a href="https://github.com/axios/axios" target="_blank">Axios</a> library is the most used HTTP client.</p><p>It can work on both the client side (AJAX requests from the client) or on the server-side (HTTP requests in a Node.js environment)</p><p>Its success may be related to Vue.js too, because a lot of Vue.js tutorials use it to query a distant API through HTTP.</p><h3>Puppeteer</h3><p><a href="https://github.com/GoogleChrome/puppeteer" target="_blank">Puppeteer</a> is one of the great stories of the year.
Made by the Google Chrome team, it's a headless Chrome browser, that is to say a browser that runs in the background and that can be piloted by code.</p><p>It can be used to do things like:</p><ul><li>Automatically testing web application UIs in real browsers.</li><li>Taking snapshots of web pages to do server-side rendering.</li><li>Generating PDF files using Google Chrome ability to save pages as PDF files.</li></ul></div></div></div></div></div></div></section><section><div><h2>Front-end Frameworks</h2><div><div><div><div><div><div id="vuejs"><div><div><img src="https://bestof.js.org/logos/vue.svg" width="50" height="50" alt="Vue.js" /></div><div><h4>Vue.js</h4><div>🖖 A progressive, incrementally-adoptable JavaScript framework for building UI on the web.</div></div><div>+40.0k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="react"><div><div><img src="https://bestof.js.org/logos/react.svg" width="50" height="50" alt="React" /></div><div><h4>React</h4><div>A declarative, efficient, and flexible JavaScript library for building user interfaces.</div></div><div>+27.8k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="angular"><div><div><img src="https://bestof.js.org/logos/angular.svg" width="50" height="50" alt="Angular" /></div><div><h4>Angular</h4><div>One framework. Mobile & desktop.</div></div><div>+12.2k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="preact"><div><div><img src="https://bestof.js.org/logos/preact.svg" width="50" height="50" alt="Preact" /></div><div><h4>Preact</h4><div>⚛️ Fast 3kB React alternative with the same modern API. Components & Virtual DOM.</div></div><div>+10.4k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="hyperapp"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/25238911?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Hyperapp" /></div><div><h4>Hyperapp</h4><div>1 KB JavaScript library for building web applications.</div></div><div>+8.1k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="dva"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/20552239?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="dva" /></div><div><div>🌱 React and redux based, lightweight and elm-style framework. (Inspired by elm and choo)</div></div><div>+5.3k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="inferno"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/14214240?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Inferno" /></div><div><h4>Inferno</h4><div>An extremely fast, React-like JavaScript library for building modern user interfaces</div></div><div>+4.6k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="moon"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/15644571?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Moon" /></div><div><div>🌙 ⚡️ A minimal, blazing fast UI library.</div></div><div>+3.7k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="angular-1"><div><div><img src="https://bestof.js.org/logos/angular.svg" width="50" height="50" alt="Angular 1" /></div><div><h4>Angular 1</h4><div>AngularJS - HTML enhanced for web apps!</div></div><div>+3.6k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="rax"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1961952?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Rax" /></div><div><div>A universal React-compatible render engine.</div></div><div>+2.6k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><p>The "front-end framework" category has been a battlefield for a while, but it seems that things are finally calming down, as we can see clearly 3 big players dominating the game.</p><h3>The Big-3: Vue, React and Angular</h3><p>Without surprise, the 3 most popular UI frameworks are <a href="http://vuejs.org" target="_blank">Vue.js</a>, <a href="https://reactjs.org" target="_blank">React</a> and <a href="https://angular.io" target="_blank">Angular</a></p><p>It's common to call these <em>frameworks</em> but, to be more accurate, the only framework is <a href="https://angular.io" target="_blank">Angular</a>, and we should call <a href="http://vuejs.org" target="_blank">Vue.js</a> and <a href="https://reactjs.org" target="_blank">React</a> <em>libraries</em>.</p><p>We talked previously about the success of <a href="http://vuejs.org" target="_blank">Vue.js</a> and its integrated approach.</p><p>By opposition, the <a href="https://reactjs.org" target="_blank">React</a> landscape is still fragmented, and developers have to make more deliberate choices about all the things that go around the view layer:</p><ul><li>Routing between pages.</li><li>How to fetch data.</li><li>How to bind forms to data.</li><li>How store the state of the application.</li></ul><p>On the contrary, the <a href="https://angular.io" target="_blank">Angular</a> ecosystem is more controlled, more stable. There is an <em>Angular Way</em> to do things.</p><p>That's probably partly why <a href="https://angular.io" target="_blank">Angular</a> has a more "corporate" image. And this image has been emphasized with the usage of static types using <a href="http://www.typescriptlang.org" target="_blank">TypeScript</a>, which resonates with backend developers familiar with types from languages like C# or Java.</p><h2>Less is more</h2><p>Behind the Big-3, it's very interesting to notice that <a href="https://preactjs.com" target="_blank">Preact</a> is number 4.
<a href="https://preactjs.com" target="_blank">Preact</a> is a smaller alternative to <a href="https://reactjs.org" target="_blank">React</a>: the same API, but in less than 3KB.</p><p>Similar, most other contenders in this category emphasize a small footprint that leads to better performance in the browser in order to differentiate themselves from the big 3.</p><p>The best example about this motto is <a href="https://hyperapp.js.org" target="_blank">Hyperapp</a>, a very hot project over the last weeks. It mixes the functional approach and the JSX syntax from <a href="https://reactjs.org" target="_blank">React</a> <strong>and</strong> a state management system inspired by <a href="http://redux.js.org" target="_blank">Redux</a>... In less than 1 KB!</p></div></div></div></div></div></div></section><section><div><h2>Node.js Frameworks</h2><div><div><div><div><div><div id="express"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/5658226?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Express" /></div><div><h4>Express</h4><div>Fast, unopinionated, minimalist web framework for width="50" height="50" alt="Keystone" /></div><div><h4>Keystone</h4><div>node.js cms and web app framework</div></div><div>+3.0k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="nest"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/28507035?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Nest" /></div><div><div>A progressive Node.js framework for building efficient and scalable server-side applications on top</div></div><div>+3.0k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div><div><h4>Feathers</h4><div>A REST and realtime API layer for modern applications.</div></div><div>+3.0k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="serverjs"><div><div><img src="https://bestof.js.org/logos/server.svg" width="50" height="50" alt="Server.js" /></div><div><h4>Server.js</h4><div>Simple and powerful server for Node.js</div></div><div>+2.9k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="loopback"><div><div><img complex integrations.</div></div><div>+2.3k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="sails"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1445252?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Sails" /></div><div><h4>Sails</h4><div>Realtime MVC Framework for Node.js</div></div><div>+2.0k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><p>Of course JavaScript is no more limited to the front-end side of web applications, it's more and more used to create the back-end too, and <a href="https://github.com/mikeal" target="_blank">Mikeal Rogers</a>, an influent member of the node.js community, predicts that <a href="https://thenewstack.io/open-source-profile-mikeal-rogers-node-js/" target="_blank">Node.js Will Overtake Java Within a Year</a>.</p><p>But unlike other languages where de-facto standards have emerged over the years (think about Ruby on Rails for Ruby, Django for Python or Laravel for PHP), there is no golden standard or recommended architecture when you want to create a new node.js server.</p><p>Despite its age, <a href="https://expressjs.com" target="_blank">Express</a> was not only the trendiest node.js framework in 2017 but it's also used as the backbone of many other frameworks or CMS, including <a href="https://feathersjs.com" target="_blank">Feathers</a>, <a href="http://www.keystonejs.com" target="_blank">Keystone</a> or <a href="https://nestjs.com/" target="_blank">Nest</a>.</p><p>It seems that Express minimalist approach perfectly matches the micro-services trend that promotes the creation of several decoupled smaller applications over the development of a single "monolith" application.</p><p>Compared to last year, 3 newcomers joined the TOP 10 node.js frameworks:</p><ul><li><a href="https://www.fastify.io" target="_blank">Fastify</a> is built as a general-purpose web framework, inspired by <a href="hapijs.com" target="_blank">Hapi</a>, but is well suited to building fast JSON-based HTTP APIs.</li><li><a href="https://serverjs.io/" target="_blank">Server.js</a> aims to be a ‘everything works out of the box’ experience.</li><li><a href="https://nestjs.com/" target="_blank">Nest</a> features an architecture familiar to Angular developers, made of modules and controller, written in TypeScript.</li></ul></div></div></div></div></div></div></section><section><div><h2>React Ecosystem</h2><div><div><div><div><div><div being only the view layer, it creates space for a whole ecosystem that is moving very fast. In this category, we included projects built on top of <a href="https://reactjs.org" target="_blank">React</a> and <a href="http://facebook.github.io/react-native/" target="_blank">React Native</a> libraries.</p><p>In 2016 <a href="https://github.com/facebookincubator/create-react-app" target="_blank">Create React App</a> solved the problem of how to start coding a React application by providing a nice set of presets, very well packaged. Facebook keeps releasing new versions very often and it was by far the most popular project in 2017 among the React ecosystem.</p><p>As an example of its success, we could mention <a href="https://stackblitz.com/" target="_blank">StackBlitz</a>, an online IDE that lets you run application created from <a href="https://github.com/facebookincubator/create-react-app" target="_blank">Create React App</a>, right from the browser, in a few seconds.</p><p>But even if <a href="https://github.com/facebookincubator/create-react-app" target="_blank">Create React App</a> is often considered as the default "starter kit" for React, developers may need more opinionated starter kits: <a href="https://www.reactboilerplate.com" target="_blank">React boilerplate</a> was the most popular project in this category, providing a lot of feature like the GraphQL integration.</p><p><a href="http://ant.design" target="_blank">Ant Design</a>, <a href="http://pro.ant.design/" target="_blank">Ant Design Pro</a> and <a href="http://www.material-ui.com" target="_blank">Material UI</a> are sets of styled React components to help developers create a web application with React components, without worrying about the styling.</p><p><a href="https://github.com/acdlite/recompose" target="_blank">Recompose</a>'s popularity denotes one of the features seasoned developers love about React: its "functional" approach, everything is just a function and <a href="https://github.com/acdlite/recompose" target="_blank">Recompose</a> provides a full set of helpers to go further in this direction.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div></section><section><div><h2>Vue Ecosystem</h2><div><div><div><div><div><div id="element"><div><div><img id="vue-material"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/23659108?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Vue material" /></div><div><h4>Vue material</h4><div>Material design for Vue.js</div></div><div>+3.7k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><div><div><h3>Guest Writer: <a href="https://twitter.com/youyuxi" target="_blank">Evan You</a></h3><p>As much as we admire Vue.js, we have to admit we're not that familiar with its ecosystem.</p><p>That's why we looked for an expert to give us their opinion on this year's stats, and who better than the creator of Vue.js himself?</p></div></div><div><img src="/img/guests/evan.jpg" /></div></div><div><p>With the rising popularity of Vue itself, many Vue ecosystem projects also enjoyed rapid growth in 2017.</p><p><a href="http://element.eleme.io/" target="_blank">Element</a> and <a href="https://iviewui.com/" target="_blank">iView</a> are the two most popular UI component kits, both focused on rapid desktop UI development. <a href="http://mint-ui.github.io/#!/en" target="_blank">Mint UI</a> and <a href="https://vux.li/" target="_blank">vux</a>, on the other hand, are the two most popular mobile-focused UI kits.</p><p><a href="https://vuetifyjs.com" target="_blank">Vuetify</a> is a Material Design component framework that can be used for both mobile and desktop web apps, and is probably the most feature rich with server-side rendering, PWA and CLI template support. There's also <a href="http://vuematerial.io" target="_blank">Vue material</a> which focuses more on providing a set components that strictly adhere to the Material Design spec.</p><p><a href="https://nuxtjs.org" target="_blank">Nuxt</a> is a higher-level framework built on top of Vue that provides a very smooth development experience for building universal, server-rendering Vue applications. It is also very versatile - you can use the same codebase to ship a normal SPA, or even generate a static site.</p><p><a href="https://weex.apache.org/" target="_blank">Weex</a> is a framework that allows users to develop native-rendering mobile apps using familiar Vue syntax and API. It is developed by Alibaba and used in production in some of the most heavily used mobile apps in the world, with a strong focus on performance.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div></section><section><div><h2>Mobile</h2><div><div><div><div><div><div id="react-native"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/69631?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="React Native" /></div><div><h4>React Native</h4><div>A framework for building native apps with React.</div></div><div>+15.6k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="weex"><div><div><img src="https://bestof.js.org/logos/weex.svg" width="50" height="50" alt="Weex" /></div><div><div>A framework for building Mobile cross-platform UI.</div></div><div>+6.5k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="ionic"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3171503?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Ionic" /></div><div><h4>Ionic</h4><div>Build amazing native and progressive web apps with open web technologies. One app running on everyth</div></div><div>+5.5k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="quasar"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/23064371?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Quasar" /></div><div><h4>Quasar</h4><div>Quasar Framework</div></div><div>+3.7k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="nativescript"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/7392261?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="NativeScript" /></div><div><h4>NativeScript</h4><div>NativeScript is an open source framework for building truly native mobile apps with JavaScript. Use</div></div><div>+2.9k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><p>JavaScript is so versatile that it can also be used to build mobile applications, meaning that you can share components between the web and the mobile platforms.</p><p>In this category, we find again the 3 main actors of the "Front-end frameworks":</p><p>Like in 2016, <a href="http://facebook.github.io/react-native/" target="_blank">React Native</a> is the trendiest solution, based on JavaScript, to build a native application, whether it's for iOS, Android or Windows systems.</p><p>As highlighted in this video <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1cI-978DHaA" target="_blank">Cross platform apps with React Native</a>, the promise: "Write Once, Run Everywhere" was fulfilled!</p></div></div></div></div></div></div></section><section><div><h2>Compilers</h2><div><div><div><div><div><div id="typescript"><div><div><img src="https://bestof.js.org/logos/typescript.svg" width="50" height="50" alt="TypeScript" /></div><div><h4>TypeScript</h4><div>TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript that compiles to clean JavaScript output.</div></div><div>+11.6k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="babel"><div><div><img JavaScript.</div></div><div>+5.7k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="flow"><div><div><img src="https://bestof.js.org/logos/flow.svg" width="50" height="50" alt="Flow" /></div><div><div>Adds static typing to JavaScript to improve developer productivity and code quality.</div></div><div>+5.1k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="reason"><div><div><img ecosystems</div></div><div>+2.1k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="purescript"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/6556677?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Purescript" /></div><div><h4>Purescript</h4><div>A strongly-typed language that compiles to Javascript</div></div><div>+1.2k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="clojurescript"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/317875?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="ClojureScript" /></div><div><h4>ClojureScript</h4><div>Clojure to JS compiler</div></div><div>+1.0k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="coffeescript"><div><div><img src="https://bestof.js.org/logos/coffeescript.svg" width="50" height="50" alt="CoffeeScript" /></div><div><h4>CoffeeScript</h4><div>Unfancy JavaScript</div></div><div>+896<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="elm"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/4359353?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Elm" /></div><div><div>Compiler for Elm, a functional language for reliable webapps.</div></div><div>+880<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><p>Here we talk about languages that compile to regular JavaScript code.</p><p>You may need such a compiler in your building workflow for 2 reasons:</p><ul><li>You want to enjoy all feature of the latest version of the JavaScript language (ES7) while making your code compatible with a maximum of Web browsers. This feature made the success of <a href="https://babeljs.io/" target="_blank">Babel</a>, which a lot of projects depend on.</li><li>You want to add new features to the language... such as "type checking".</li></ul><p>One of the hottest questions that divide developers is: types or not types?</p><p>JavaScript has basic dynamic types but not static types. A lot of developers feel like they need types in their code, especially in big code base, to make it more robust and easier to read/understand.</p><p>And then, if you think you need types, the 2 main contenders are: <a href="http://www.typescriptlang.org" target="_blank">TypeScript</a>, provided by Microsoft and <a href="https://flow.org/" target="_blank">Flow</a>, provided by Facebook (and used on their main projects: <a href="https://reactjs.org" target="_blank">React</a>, <a href="http://facebook.github.io/react-native/" target="_blank">React Native</a>, <a href="http://facebook.github.io/jest/" target="_blank">Jest</a>...)</p><p>Read this article from <a href="https://github.com/thejameskyle" target="_blank">James Kyle</a> to understand the difference: <a href="https://medium.com/the-thinkmill/adopting-flow-typescript-3549a3a36d51" target="_blank">A Comparison Between Adopting Flow or TypeScript</a></p></div></div></div></div></div></div></section><section><div><h2>Build Tools</h2><div><div><div><div><div><div id="parcel"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/32607881?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Parcel" /></div><div><h4>Parcel</h4><div>📦🚀 Blazing fast, zero configuration web application bundler</div></div><div>+14.0k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="webpack"><div><div><img src="https://bestof.js.org/logos/webpack.svg" width="50" height="50" alt="Webpack" /></div><div><h4>Webpack</h4><div>A bundler for javascript and friends. Packs many modules into a few bundled assets. Code Splitting a</div></div><div>+13.1k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="gulp"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/6200624?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Gulp" /></div><div><div>The streaming build system</div></div><div>+3.6k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="rollup"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/12554859?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Rollup" /></div><div><h4>Rollup</h4><div>Next-generation ES6 module bundler</div></div><div>+3.5k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="poi"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/8784712?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Poi" /></div><div><div>Delightful web development.</div></div><div>+2.7k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="fusebox"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/23119087?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="FuseBox" /></div><div><h4>FuseBox</h4><div>A blazing fast js bundler/loader with a comprehensive API</div></div><div>+2.5k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="browserify"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/6320506?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Browserify" /></div><div><h4>Browserify</h4><div>browser-side require() the node.js way</div></div><div>+1.1k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><p>It's maybe the biggest surprise of the year, the trendiest building tool is <a href="https://parceljs.org" target="_blank">Parcel</a>, a brand new project that gathered more than 14,000 stars since the project was launched on GitHub in August.</p><p><a href="https://parceljs.org" target="_blank">Parcel</a> offers all the goodies of modern web development with a killer feature: zero configuration!</p><p>That's the main difference with <a href="https://webpack.js.org" target="_blank">Webpack</a>, that relies on a whole ecosystem of plugins called "loaders".</p><p>Do not misunderstand the numbers, <a href="https://webpack.js.org" target="_blank">Webpack</a> is still the most popular bundler for modern applications, with a total of 35,000 stars on GitHub and more than 500 contributors.</p><p>A lot of projects use it under the hood, including <a href="https://github.com/facebookincubator/create-react-app" target="_blank">Create React App</a> and <a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.org" target="_blank">Gatsby</a>, 2 of the most popular projects of the year.</p><p><a href="https://webpack.js.org" target="_blank">Webpack</a> keeps on evolving, the version 2 lets developers implement features like "code splitting" very easily, through dynamic imports.</p><p>While <a href="https://webpack.js.org" target="_blank">Webpack</a> and <a href="https://parceljs.org" target="_blank">Parcel</a> both target the building process of web <strong>applications</strong>, <a href="http://rollupjs.org" target="_blank">Rollup</a> targets <strong>libraries</strong>. It focuses on performance by taking advantage of ES6 modules.</p><p><a href="http://rollupjs.org" target="_blank">Rollup</a> is used by some major libraries and it's worth to mention that the <a href="https://reactjs.org" target="_blank">React</a> team migrated their build system from <a href="http://browserify.org/" target="_blank">Browserify</a> to <a href="http://rollupjs.org" target="_blank">Rollup</a> in 2017.</p><p>From the <a href="https://reactjs.org/blog/2017/12/15/improving-the-repository-infrastructure.html" target="_blank">React blog</a></p><blockquote><p>Rollup is a perfect fit for libraries like React that can be pre-built and then integrated into apps.</p></blockquote><p><a href="https://poi.js.org" target="_blank">Poi</a> has the same goal as <a href="https://parceljs.org" target="_blank">Parcel</a>: a build tool for modern web applications and libraries, it's zero-config by default but gives you the ability to extend via presets.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div></section><section><div><h2>Testing Frameworks</h2><div><div><div><div><div><div id="jest"><div><div><img src="https://bestof.js.org/logos/jest.svg" width="50" height="50" alt="Jest" /></div><div><div>🃏 Delightful JavaScript Testing.</div></div><div>+7.1k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="ava"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/8527916?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="AVA" /></div><div><div>Futuristic JavaScript test runner</div></div><div>+4.8k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="mocha"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/8770005?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Mocha" /></div><div><h4>Mocha</h4><div>☕️ simple, flexible, fun javascript test framework for node.js & the browser</div></div><div>+3.1k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="jasmine"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/4624349?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Jasmine" /></div><div><h4>Jasmine</h4><div>Simple JavaScript testing framework for browsers and node.js</div></div><div>+1.2k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="tape"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/12631?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Tape" /></div><div><div>tap-producing test harness for node and browsers</div></div><div>+1.0k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><p>As we predicted <a href="/2016/en#test-framework" target="_blank">last year</a> (it's the first time we predicted something right!), <a href="http://facebook.github.io/jest/" target="_blank">Jest</a> became the trendiest testing framework in 2017.</p><p>It was first created by Facebook to run tests for React components, but its evolution has been very fast over the last months (already 22 majors versions released!) and it can be used to write tests for front-end and back-end code.</p><p>Jest shines because of several points:</p><ul><li>No configuration needed, the defaults settings match the usually needs</li><li>Great developer experience (intelligent watch mode, very nice error reporting...)</li><li>Syntax close to <a href="https://mochajs.org" target="_blank">Mocha</a>, a lot of developers are familiar with <code>describe</code> and <code>it</code> keywords</li><li>No extra library required to make assertions, it's "battery included".</li><li>Features a unique "snapshot" mode that records automatically the response expected for future tests.</li></ul><p><a href="https://github.com/avajs/ava" target="_blank">AVA</a>, number one last year, has still a lot of traction.</p><p>It has been created by <a href="https://github.com/sindresorhus" target="_blank">Sindre Sorhus</a> who uses it on all his projects... and that means a lot of great projects!</p><p>It emphasizes on speed by running tests in parallel, it has a smaller footprint and is closer to testing standards, with a syntax close to test frameworks like <a href="https://github.com/substack/tape" target="_blank">Tape</a>.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div></section><section><div><h2>IDEs & Editors</h2><div><div><div><div><div><div id="vs-code"><div><div><img src="https://bestof.js.org/logos/vscode.svg" width="50" height="50" alt="VS Code" /></div><div><h4>VS Code</h4><div>Visual Studio Code</div></div><div>+20.2k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="atom"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1089146?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Atom" /></div><div><div>The hackable text editor</div></div><div>+9.1k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="reactide"><div><div><img development. http://reactide.io</div></div><div>+7.4k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="brackets"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/476009?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Brackets" /></div><div><h4>Brackets</h4><div>An open source code editor for the web, written in JavaScript, HTML and CSS.</div></div><div>+1.9k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="nuclide"><div><div><img src="https://bestof.js.org/logos/nuclide.svg" width="50" height="50" alt="Nuclide" /></div><div><h4>Nuclide</h4><div>An open IDE for web and native mobile development, built on top of Atom</div></div><div>+1.4k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><p>Here we talk about the text editors from the open source world, built with web technologies (sorry for Sublime users!).</p><p>In 2016, <a href="https://code.visualstudio.com" target="_blank">VS Code</a>, backed by Microsoft and <a href="https://atom.io" target="_blank">Atom</a>, backed by GitHub were really close at the top of the category.</p><p>They also led the way in 2017 but <a href="https://code.visualstudio.com" target="_blank">VS Code</a> took a big advantage over its rival.</p><p>Every month, a new version of <a href="https://code.visualstudio.com" target="_blank">VS Code</a> is released bringing, more and more helpful features to the IDE, without sacrificing performance too much.
Out of the box, without installing anything, you have a great set of features:</p><ul><li>Git integration</li><li>Autocomplete for a lot of things: JavaScript syntax, local file paths when you <code>require</code> or <code>import</code> a module, NPM packages names...</li><li>React syntax integration</li></ul><p>If you add <a href="https://prettier.io/" target="_blank">Prettier</a> to the mix, asking the editor to automatically format your files every time you save, you have the perfect combo to enjoy code poetry!</p></div></div></div></div></div></div></section><section><div><h2>CSS in JavaScript</h2><div><div><div><div><div><div id="styled-components"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/20658825?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Styled Components" /></div><div><h4>Styled Components</h4><div>Visual primitives for the component age. Use the best bits of ES6 and CSS to style your apps without</div></div><div>+8.7k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="css-modules"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/12612655?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="CSS Modules" /></div><div><h4>CSS Modules</h4><div>Documentation about css-modules</div></div><div>+2.9k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="polished"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/20658825?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Polished" /></div><div><h4>Polished</h4><div>A lightweight toolset for writing styles in JavaScript ✨</div></div><div>+2.9k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="glamorous"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/476675?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Glamorous" /></div><div><h4>Glamorous</h4><div>💄 Maintainable CSS with React</div></div><div>+2.9k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="emotion"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/31557565?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Emotion" /></div><div><h4>Emotion</h4><div>⚡️ The Next Generation of CSS-in-JS</div></div><div>+2.5k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="styled-jsx"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/14985020?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Styled JSX" /></div><div><h4>Styled JSX</h4><div>Full CSS support for JSX without compromises</div></div><div>+1.7k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="aphrodite"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/15455?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Aphrodite" /></div><div><h4>Aphrodite</h4><div>Framework-agnostic CSS-in-JS with support for server-side rendering, browser prefixing, and minimum</div></div><div>+1.5k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="glamor"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/18808?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Glamor" /></div><div><h4>Glamor</h4><div>inline css for react et al</div></div><div>+1.3k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="jss"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/9503099?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="JSS" /></div><div><div>JSS is an authoring tool for CSS which uses JavaScript as a host language.</div></div><div>+1.3k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="radium"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/5078602?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Radium" /></div><div><h4>Radium</h4><div>A toolchain for React component styling.</div></div><div>+1.2k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><p>There is still no consensus about the best way to style React components.</p><p>You can use a ready-made component toolkit like <a href="http://www.material-ui.com" target="_blank">Material UI</a> or <a href="http://ant.design" target="_blank">Ant Design</a> if your needs are pretty "standard" and you don't need too much customization.</p><p>Or, if you need more flexibility, you can do it the "old way", using global CSS styles from a popular CSS toolkit like <a href="http://getbootstrap.com" target="_blank">Bootstrap</a> or <a href="https://bulma.io" target="_blank">Bulma</a>, and assigning appropriate <code>className</code>s to your components. But then your component is not self-contained anymore, since its style is being managed elsewhere.</p><p>To address this issue, the "CSS in JavaScript" category has emerged.</p><p>The concept is simple: with React you already manage <strong>both</strong> your component logic and its template using JavaScript. Why not go further and encapsulate the styles in your components, using JavaScript for styling too?</p><p><a href="http://styled-components.com" target="_blank">Styled Components</a> was by far the trendiest project in this category this year. It lets developers include regular CSS syntax inside the React components, using a recent addition to the JavaScript language: tagged template literals.</p><p><a href="https://github.com/css-modules/css-modules" target="_blank">CSS Modules</a>, number 2 in this category, adopts a more hybrid approach. It lets developers write styles in the language of their choice (regular CSS, Sass, <a href="http://lesscss.org" target="_blank">Less</a>, <a href="http://stylus-lang.com/" target="_blank">Stylus</a>), using files that are located next to the related components and that are <strong>imported</strong> into the components</p><p><a href="http://markdalgleish.com/" target="_blank">Mark Dalgleish</a>, one of the authors of <a href="https://github.com/css-modules/css-modules" target="_blank">CSS Modules</a>, wrote one of the most interesting articles about the CSS-in-JavaScript approach: <a href="https://medium.com/seek-blog/a-unified-styling-language-d0c208de2660" target="_blank">A Unified Styling Language</a>. This article is highly recommended for people who might be somewhat skeptical about this new technique.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div></section><section><div><h2>Static Sites</h2><div><div><div><div><div><div id="gatsby"><div><div><img src="https://www.gatsbyjs.org/gatsby-negative.svg" width="50" height="50" alt="Gatsby" /></div><div><h4>Gatsby</h4><div>⚛️📄🚀 Blazing fast static site generator for React</div></div><div>+9.7k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="hexo"><div><div><img Node.js.</div></div><div>+6.2k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="react-static"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/5400727?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="React Static" /></div><div><h4>React Static</h4><div>⚛️ 🚀 A progressive static-site generator for React.</div></div><div>+3.0k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="phenomic"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/28756976?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Phenomic" /></div><div><h4>Phenomic</h4><div>Modular website compiler ⚡️</div></div><div>+1.4k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div><div><div id="metalsmith"><div><div><img src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/819518?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="Metalsmith" /></div><div><h4>Metalsmith</h4><div>An extremely simple, pluggable static site generator.</div></div><div>+1.0k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><p>Static site generators (or "SSG") are tools that generate a bunch of .html, .css and JavaScript files that you can deploy on any web server without the fuss of setting up a database.
Static web sites are fast, robust and easy to maintain.</p><p>Number 2 in 2016, <a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.org" target="_blank">Gatsby</a> gets revenge in 2017. It comes with a lot of great features to optimize your static site:</p><ul><li>Fast browsing & exporting</li><li>Aggressive preloading</li><li>Intelligent code splitting (templates + page data)</li></ul><p><a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.org" target="_blank">Gatsby</a> uses <a href="https://reactjs.org" target="_blank">React</a> as the view layer and GraphQL to query the content at the building time.
It has a strong community and <a href="https://reactjs.org" target="_blank">React official web site</a> itself is built with Gatsby.</p><p><a href="https://github.com/nozzle/react-static" target="_blank">React Static</a> is the newcomer in this category.
It aims to be a lighter alternative to <a href="https://www.gatsbyjs.org" target="_blank">Gatsby</a>, with a focus on performance and simplicity, inspired by <a href="https://github.com/facebookincubator/create-react-app" target="_blank">Create React App</a> project.</p><p>It's worth to mention that both <a href="https://zeit.co/blog/next4" target="_blank">Next.js</a> and <a href="https://nuxtjs.org" target="_blank">Nuxt</a> projects can also be used as Static Site Generators.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div></section><section><div><h2>GraphQL</h2><div><div><div><div><div><div id="gatsby"><div><div><img src="https://www.gatsbyjs.org/gatsby-negative.svg" alt="GraphQL" /></div><div><h4>GraphQL</h4><div>GraphQL is a query language and execution engine tied to any backend service.</div></div><div>+2.8k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" src="https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/17219288?v=3&s=50" width="50" height="50" alt="GraphQL Playground" /></div><div><h4>GraphQL Playground</h4><div>🎮  GraphQL IDE for better development workflows (GraphQL Subscriptions, interactive docs & collabor</div></div><div>+1.3k<img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," width="14" height="16" alt="☆" /></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div><div><div><div><p>When future historians look back at the history of GraphQL, 2017 might very well be a turning point. </p><p>Major companies such as <a href="https://open.nytimes.com/react-relay-and-graphql-under-the-hood-of-the-times-website-redesign-22fb62ea9764" target="_blank">the New York Times</a> have started adopting GraphQL, and on the library front both <a href="https://code.facebook.com/posts/1362748677097871/relay-modern-simpler-faster-more-extensible/" target="_blank">Relay</a> and <a href="https://dev-blog.apollodata.com/apollo-client-2-0-5c8d0affcec7" target="_blank">Apollo</a> (the two main GraphQL client libraries) released major updates this year. </p><p>Beyond these two big players, companies like <a href="http://www.graph.cool/" target="_blank">Graphcool</a> have also released a plethora of tools and libraries, and GraphQL-powered full-stack frameworks like <a href="http://vulcanjs.org" target="_blank">Vulcan</a> are also starting to create their own niche. </p><p>It's also worth mentioning that this year's most popular static site generator <a href="http://gatsbyjs.org" target="_blank">Gatsby</a> also uses GraphQL as part of its data processing chain. </p><p>With so many players venturing out in the GraphQL galaxy, it's only a matter of time before the technology becomes a widespread alternative to REST. </p></div></div></div></div></div></div></section><div id="conclusion"><div><div><h2>Conclusion</h2></div><div><div><p>We hope you enjoyed this round-up of the JavaScript universe in 2017.</p><p>We have seen by the numbers that <a href="http://vuejs.org" target="_blank">Vue.js</a> is once again the winner of this year, and its success is not slowing down.</p><p>The <a href="https://reactjs.org" target="_blank">React</a> eco-system keeps growing up, after finally putting its license-related issues behind it.</p><p>But if we had to pick one project among the <em>2017 Rising Stars</em> it would be <a href="https://prettier.io/" target="_blank">Prettier</a>. It's so nice to be able to write code without worrying about formatting!</p><p>And for another point view on the latest trends, be sure to also check out the <a href="https://stateofjs.com/" target="_blank">State of JavaScript 2017 survey</a>, where we collected and analyzed responses from more than 23,000 developers.</p><p>So going forward, which projects do you think will be the next <em>JavaScript Rising Stars</em> in 2018?</p><ul><li>A new framework based on <a href="http://facebook.github.io/graphql/" target="_blank">GraphQL</a>?</li><li>A library that takes advantage of the new WebAssembly standard to create a unique experience in the browser?</li></ul><p>Let us know what you think! In the meantime, thank you for your attention, and feel free to share this article or reach us on <a href="https://github.com/bestofjs/javascript-risingstars" target="_blank">Github</a> if you have any feedback… and see you next year!</p><hr /></div></div></div></div></div></div><section><div><div><p>This article is also available in:</p><p><a href="/2017/zh" target="_blank">中文</a></p><p><a href="/2017/fr" target="_blank">Français</a></p><p><a href="/2017/es" target="_blank">Español</a></p></div></div></section><div id="footer"><div><p><a href="https://bestof.js.org" target="_blank">bestof.js.org</a> is a project created by <a href="https://michaelrambeau.com/" target="_blank">Michael Rambeau</a>, from Osaka, Japan.</p></div></div></div></div></div><div><h3>Like On Github</h3><div><div>*Title (label for the link)</div></div><div><div>*Comment (commit message)</div></div><div id="action-btns"><div id="logh_btn_save">Saving...</div><div id="logh_btn_cancel">Cancel</div></div></div>
